items.title: Document title
items.help_text: The title of the metadata document (which may be the title of the database itself). The "metadata document" is the metadata file (XML or JSON file) that is being generated.

items.title: Document ID
items.help_text: A unique identifier for the database metadata document. This identifier must be unique in the catalog where the metadata are intended to be published. Ideally, the identifier should also be unique globally. This is different from the "Primary ID" in section Database description / Title statement, although it is good practice to generate identifiers that establish a clear connection between these two identifiers. The Document ID could also include the metadata document version identifier. For example, if the "Primary ID" of the World Development Indicators (WDI) database - April 2022 is "WDI_2022-04, the "Document ID" in the Metadata information could be “WB_WDI_2022-04” if the metadata are produced by the World Bank. Each organization should establish systematic rules to generate such IDs. A validation rule can be set (using a regular expression) in user templates to enforce a specific ID format. The identifier may not contain blank spaces.

items.title: Metadata producers

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the person or organization who produced the metadata or contributed to its production.

props.title: Abbreviation
props.help_text: The abbreviation (or acronym) of the organization that is referenced in "Name".

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: The affiliation of the person or organization mentioned in "Name".

props.title: Role
props.help_text: The specific role of the person or organization mentioned in "Name" in the production of the metadata.

items.help_text: The metadata producer is the person or organization with the financial and/or administrative responsibility for the processes whereby the metadata document was created. This is a "Recommended" element. For catalog administration purposes, information on the producer and on the date of metadata production is useful.

items.title: Production date
items.help_text: The date the metadata on this database was produced (not distributed or archived), preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYY-MM). A validation rule can be set in user templates to enforce a date format. This is a "Recommended" element, as information on the producer and on the date of metadata production is useful for catalog administration purposes.

items.title: Version
items.help_text: The version of the metadata document (not the version of the database itself).

items.title: Primary ID
items.help_text:
A unique identifier of the database. For example, the World Bank’s World Development Indicators database published in April 2020 could have Main identifier = “WB_WDI_APR_2020”.
The "Primary ID" (also referred to as IDNO) is a unique identification number used to identify the database. A unique identifier is required for cataloguing purpose, so this element is declared as "Required". The identifier will allow users to cite the database properly. The identifier must be unique within the catalog. Ideally, it should also be globally unique; the recommended option is to obtain a Digital Object Identifier (DOI) for the study. Alternatively, the "Primary ID" can be constructed by an organization using a consistent scheme. Note that the schema allows you to provide more than one identifier for a same study (in element "Other identifiers"); a catalog-specific identifier is thus not incompatible with a globally unique identifier like a DOI. A validation rule can be set (using a regular expression) in user templates to enforce a specific ID format. The identifier may not contain blank spaces.

items.title: Other identifiers
items.help_text: This repeatable element is used to enter identifiers (IDs) other than the "Primary ID" (IDNO). It can for example be a Digital Object Identifier (DOI). The "Primary ID" can be repeated here (the "Primary ID" does not provide a "Type" parameter, so if a DOI or other standard ID type is used as main identifier, it is recommended to repeat it here with the identification of the type).

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of identifier. For example: “DOI”, or "ISBN".

props.title: Identifier
props.help_text: The identifier itself.

items.title: Title
items.help_text: The title is the name by which the database is formally known. Make sure to use a unique title for each distinct database (or version of). It is good practice to include the year of production in the title (and possibly the month, or quarter, if a new version of the database is released more than once a year). For example, “World Development Indicators, April 2020”. Pay attention to the consistent use of capitalization in the title.

items.title: Subtitle
items.help_text: The database subtitle can be used when there is a need to distinguish characteristics of a database. This element will rarely be used. Pay attention to the consistent use of capitalization in the subtitle.

items.title: Alternate title
items.help_text: This can be an acronym, or an alternative name of the database. For example, “WDI April 2020”.

items.title: Translated title
items.help_text: The title of the database in a secondary language (if more than one other language, they may be entered as one string, as this element is not repeatable). Special characters should be properly displayed, such as accents and other stress marks or different alphabets.

items.title: Authoring entity

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the person or organization who maintains the contents of the database (back-end). Write the name in full (use the element "Abbreviation" to capture the acronym of the organization, if relevant).

props.title: Affiliation
props.name: affiliation
props.help_text: The affiliation of the person or organization mentioned in "Name".

props.title: Abbreviation
props.help_text: Abbreviated name (acronym) of the organization mentioned in "Name".

props.title: Email
props.help_text: The public email contact of the person or organizations mentioned in name. It is good practice to provide a service account email address, not a personal one.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: A link (URL) to the website of the entity mentioned in name.

items.help_text: This set of five elements is used to identify the organization(s) or person(s) who are the main producers/curators of the database. Note that a similar element is available at the indicator/series level.

items.title: Abstract
items.help_text: The abstract is a brief description of the database. It can for example include a short statement on the database scope and coverage (not in detail, as other fields are available for that purpose), objectives, history, and expected audience.

items.title: Database type
items.help_text: The type of database.

items.title: Date created
items.help_text: This is the date the database was created. The date should be entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD, or YYYY-MM, or YYYY).

items.title: Date published
items.help_text: This is the date the database was made public. The date should be entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD, or YYYY-MM, or YYYY).

items.title: Version

props.title: Version
props.help_text: A label for the version. The version specification will be determined by a curator or a data manager under conventions determined by the authoring entity.

props.title: Date
props.help_text: The date the version was released. The date should be entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD, or YYYY-MM, or YYYY).

props.title: Responsibility
props.help_text: The organization or person in charge of this version of the database.

props.title: Notes
props.help_text: Additional information on this version of the database. Notes can for example be used to document how this version differs from previous ones.

items.help_text: A database rarely remains static; it will be regularly updated and upgraded. The version element is a compound element and contains important information regarding the updating of the database. This includes any extension of the database (adding new series data), appending existing data, correcting existing data, etc.

items.title: Update frequency
items.help_text: Indicates at which frequency the database is updated (for example, “annual” or “quarterly”). The use of a controlled vocabulary is recommended. If a database contains many indicators, the update frequency may vary by indicator (e.g., some may be updated on a monthly or quarterly basis while others are only updated annually). The information provided in "Update frequency" will correspond to the frequency of update for the indicators that are most frequently updated.

items.title: Update schedule

props.title: Update
props.help_text: A description of the schedule of updates or a date entered in ISO 8601 format.

items.help_text: The update schedule is intended to provide users with information on scheduled updates. This is a repeatable field that allows for capturing specific dates, but this information would then have to be regularly updated. Often a single description will be used, which would avoid having to regularly update the metadata. For example, “The database is updated in January, April, July, October of each year.”

items.title: Languages

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The official name of the language being supported; it is recommended to use a name from the ISO 639-1 language name list.

props.title: Code
props.help_text: The code of the language mentioned in "Name", preferably the three letter ISO 639-1 code.

items.help_text: This set of elements is provided to list the languages that are supported in the database.

items.title: Themes

props.title: ID
props.help_text: The unique identifier of the theme. It can be a sequential number, or the identifier of the theme in a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Theme
props.help_text: The label of the theme associated with the data.

props.title: Parent ID
props.help_text: When a hierarchical (nested) controlled vocabulary is used, the "Parent ID" field can be used to indicate a higher-level theme to which this theme belongs.

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The name of the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: A link to the controlled vocabulary mentioned in field ‘vocabulary’.

items.help_text: Themes provide a general idea of the research that might guide the creation and/or demand for the series. A theme is broad and is likely also subject to a community based definition or list. A controlled vocabulary should be used. This element will rarely be used (the element "Topics" will be used more often).

items.title: Topics

props.title: ID
props.help_text: The unique identifier of the topic. It can be a sequential number, or the identifier of the topic in a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Topic
props.help_text: The label of the topic associated with the data.

props.title: Parent ID
props.help_text: When a hierarchical (nested) controlled vocabulary is used, the "Parent ID" field can be used to indicate a higher-level topic to which this topic belongs.

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The name of the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: A link to the controlled vocabulary mentioned in field `vocabulary’.

items.help_text: The topics field indicates the broad substantive topic(s) that the indicator/series covers. A topic classification facilitates referencing and searches in electronic survey catalogs. Topics should be selected from a standard controlled vocabulary such as the Council of European Social Science Data Archives (CESSDA) topic classification.

items.title: Keywords

props.title: Keyword
props.help_text: A keyword (or phrase).

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The name of the controlled vocabulary from which the keyword was extracted, if any.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL of the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

items.help_text: Words or phrases that describe salient aspects of a data collection’s content. This can be used for building keyword indexes and for classification and retrieval purposes. Keywords can be selected from a standard thesaurus, preferably an international, multilingual thesaurus. The list of keywords can include keywords extracted from one or more controlled vocabularies and user-defined keywords.

items.title: Dimensions
items.help_text: The dimensions available for the series included in the database. For example, "country, year".

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the dimension.

props.title: Label
props.help_text: A label for the dimension.

items.title: Sponsors
items.help_text: The source(s) of funds for the production and maintenance of the database. If different funding agencies sponsored different stages of the database development, use the role attribute to distinguish their respective contributions.

props.title: Name
props.help_text: Name of the funding agency/sponsor.

props.title: Abbreviation
props.help_text: Abbreviation of the funding/sponsoring agency mentioned in "Name".

props.title: Role
props.help_text: The role of the funding/sponsoring agency mentioned in "Name".

props.title: Grant
props.help_text: Grant or award number. If an agency provided more than one grant, list all grants separated with a “;”.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: URL of the sponsor agency mentioned in "Name".

items.title: Acknowledgments

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the person or agency being recognized for supporting the database.

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: Affiliation of the person or agency recognized or acknowledged for supporting the database.

props.title: Role
props.help_text: Role of the person or agency that is being recognized or acknowledged for supporting the database.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: Website URL or email of the person or organization being recognized or acknowledged for supporting the database.

items.help_text: An itemized list of person(s) and/or organization(s) other than sponsors and contributors already mentioned in metadata elements contributors and sponsors whose contribution to the database must be acknowledged. NOTE: Another element ("Acknowledgment statement") is available as an alternative to this itemized list of acknowledgments.

items.title: Acknowledgment statement
items.help_text: An overall statement of acknowledgment, which can be used as an alternative (or supplement) to the itemized list provided in "Acknowledgments".

items.title: Contacts

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the contact person that should be contacted. Instead of the name of an individual (which would be subject to change and require frequent update of the metadata), a title can be provided here (e.g. “data helpdesk”).

props.title: Role
props.help_text: The specific role of the contact person mentioned in "Name". This will be used when multiple contacts are listed, and is intended to help users direct their questions and requests to the right contact person.

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: The organization or affiliation of the contact person mentioned in "Name".

props.title: Email
props.help_text: The email address of the person or organization mentioned in "Name". Avoid using personal email accounts; the use of an anonymous email is recommended (e.g., “helpdesk@….org”)

props.title: Phone
props.help_text: The phone number of the person or organization mentioned in "Name".

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL of the agency (typically, a URL to a “contact us” web page)

items.help_text: The contacts element provides the public interface for questions associated with the development and maintenance of the database. There could be various contacts provided depending upon the organization.

items.title: Errata

props.title: Date
props.help_text: The date the erratum was published.

props.title: Description
props.help_text: A description of the error and measures taken to remedy.

items.help_text: A list of errata at the database level. Note that an "errata" element is also available in the schema used for the description of indicators/series.

items.title: Notes

props.title: Note
props.help_text: A free-text note.

items.help_text: This element is provided to add notes that are relevant for describing the database, that cannot be provided in other metadata elements.

items.title: Countries

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the country.

props.title: Code
props.help_text: The code of the country. The use of the ISO 3166-1 alpha-3 codes is recommended.

items.help_text: A list of countries for which data are available in the database. This element is somewhat redundant with the element "Geographic areas". The list of countries should be entered in "Countries".

items.title: Geographic areas
items.help_text: A list of geographic areas (regions, states, provinces, etc.) for which data are available in the database. This can contain sub-national areas, supra-national regions, or non-administrative area names. The type element is used to indicate the type of geographic area. Countries should be provided in the element "Countries".

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the geographic area, e.g., "World", "Sub-Saharan Africa", "Low-income countries".

props.title: Code
props.help_text: The code of the geographic unit.

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of geographic area, e.g. "state", "region", or "province".

items.title: Note on geographic coverage
items.help_text: The note can be used to capture additional information on the geographic coverage of the database.

items.title: Bounding boxes

props.title: West
props.help_text: West longitude of the bounding box.

props.title: East
props.help_text: East longitude of the bounding box.

props.title: South
props.help_text: South latitude of the bounding box.

props.title: North
props.help_text: North latitude of the bounding box.

items.help_text: This element is used to define one or multiple geographic bounding box(es), which are the rectangular fundamental geometric description of the geographic coverage of the data. A bounding box is defined by west and east longitudes and north and south latitudes, and includes the largest geographic extent of the dataset’s geographic coverage. The bounding box provides the geographic coordinates of the top left (north/west) and bottom-right (south/east) corners of a rectangular area. This element can be used in catalogs as the first pass of a coordinate-based search. The valid range of latitude in degrees is -90 and +90 for the southern and northern hemisphere, respectively. Longitude is in the range -180 and +180 specifying coordinates west and east of the Prime Meridian, respectively.

items.title: Geographic granularity
items.help_text: Whereas the "Geographic areas" element lists the various geographic levels for which there is data in the database, the "Geographic granularity" element will provide information on the geographic levels for which information is available in the database. For example: “The database contains data at the national, provincial (admin 1) and district (admin 2) levels.”

items.title: Geographic area count
items.help_text: The number of geographic areas for which data are provided in the database. The World Bank World Development Indicators for example provides data for 262 different areas (which includes countries and territories, geographic regions, and other country groupings).

items.title: Time coverage

props.title: Start
props.help_text: Indicates the start date of the period covered by the data (across all series) in the database. The date should be provided in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD, or YYYY-MM, or YYYY).

props.title: End
props.help_text: Indicates the end date of the period covered by the data (across all series) in the database. The date should be provided in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD, or YYYY-MM, or YYYY).

items.help_text: The time coverage is the time span of all the data contained in the database across all series.

items.title: Time coverage note
items.help_text: The element is used to annotate and/or describe auxiliary information related to the time coverage described in "Time coverage".

items.title: Periodicity

props.title: Period
props.help_text: The periodicity of the time series included in the database, for example, “annual”, “quarterly”, or “monthly”.

items.help_text: The periodicity of the data describes the periodicity of the indicators contained in the database. A database can contain series covering different periods, in which case the information will be repeated for each type of periodicity. A controlled vocabulary should be used.

items.title: Access modes

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The access type, e.g. “Application Programming Interface (API)”, “Bulk download in CSV format”, “On-line query interface”, etc.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL corresponding to the access mode mentioned in type.

props.title: Note
props.help_text: This element allows for annotating any specific information associated with the access mode mentioned in type.

items.help_text: This repeatable set of elements describes the different modes and formats in which the database is made accessible. When more than one mode of access is provided, describe them separately.

items.title: Database URL
items.help_text: The link to the public interface of the database (home page).

items.title: Other links

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL for the associated link.

props.title: Description
props.help_text: A brief description of the link, in relation to the database.

items.help_text: This field allows for the association of auxiliary links referring to the database.

items.title: Copyright
items.help_text: The copyright attached to the database, if any.

items.title: License

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the license, for example “Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license (CC-BY 4.0)”.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: A URL to a description of the license, for example “https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/”.

props.title: Note
props.help_text: Any additional information to qualify the license requirements.

items.help_text: This set of elements is used to describe the access license(s) attached to the database.

items.title: Disclaimer
items.help_text: If the agency responsible for managing the database has determined that there may be some liability as a result of the data, the element may be used to provide a disclaimer statement.

items.title: Citation requirement
items.help_text: The citation requirement for the database (i.e. how users should cite the database in publications and reports).

items.title: Tags

props.title: Tag
props.help_text: A user-defined tag.

props.title: Tag group
props.help_text: A user-defined group (optional) to which the tag belongs. Grouping tags allows implementation of controlled facets in data catalogs.

items.help_text: Tags, especially when organized in tag groups, provide a powerful and flexible solution to enable custom facets (filters) in data catalogs.
